R. 30 mad. 326. ssarily meant a Court to which Indian Civil Procedure Code applied i. e., a Court in what was British India. The Court at Morena no- t being such a Court the decree could not be transferred to it under the Indian Code of Civil Procedure and ss. 38 and 39 were inapplicable to justify such a transfer. The decree, it was then argued, was executable under s. 43 of the Indian Civil Procedure Code as amended by the Adaptation of Laws Order of June 5, 1950, which had retrospective effect as from January 26, 1950. arguments.claim: The Court had no power to transfer the decree under s. 38 to the Court in Morena

arguments.claim: Under ss. 38 and 39 of the Indian CPC, a decree could be sent for execution to any Court, where Court means a place where justice was administered

anchor.surface_text: It was contended by Mr. N. S. Bindra counsel for the respondent that under ss. 38 and 39 of the Indian Code of Civil Procedure a decree could be sent for execution to any Court, the expression Court being understood as a place where justice was administered and for this reliance was placed on Manawala Goundan v. Kumarappa Reddy

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e said above Court in the section means a companyrt to which the Indian Code of Civil Procedure applies and number any Court. Similarly at the relevan

arguments.court_reasoning: That definition not applicable; Court in s.38 means court to which Indian CPC applies, not any place administering justice

arguments.claim: The decree was executable under s. 43 of the Indian CPC as amended by Adaptation of Laws Order 1950, reading 'Part B State' as 'Part A State'

anchor.surface_text: The decree, it was then argued, was executable under s. 43 of the Indian Civil Procedure Code as amended by the Adaptation of Laws Order of June 5, 1950, which had retrospective effect as from January 26, 1950. After the amendment that section reads - S 43 Any decree passed-  a  by a Civil Court in Part B State, or  b   c  may, if it cannot be executed within the jurisdiction of the Court by which it was passed, be executed in manner herein provided within the jurisdiction of any Court in the States. The argument was that in the present case the expression in a Part B State, should be read as if the expression was in a Part A State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal rule of interpretation; cannot substitute 'Part A State' for 'Part B State' in s.43 despite amendment's retrospectivity

holdings.text: The Indian Civil Procedure Code was not extended to Madhya Bharat till April 1, 1951, by Act 11 of 1951

anchor.surface_text: Besides the Indian Civil Procedure Code was not extended to Madhya Bharat till April 1, 1951, by Act 11 of 1951. holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical application of Indian CPC limited to British India until statutory extension via Act 11/1951

holdings.text: The decrees of foreign courts were, under the Gwalior Code of which Morena was a part, executable neither under s. 233 which required a suit to be brought on the basis of foreign decrees nor under the Madhya Bharat Code of Civil Procedure

anchor.surface_text: The decrees of foreign courts were, under the Gwalior Code of which Morena was a part, executable neither under s. 233 which required a suit to be brought on the basis of foreign decrees nor under the Madhya Bharat Code of Civil Procedure. The decree therefore could not be executed in Morena under s.43 of the Indian Code of Civil Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Local procedural codes did not permit direct execution of foreign decrees; required fresh suit

holdings.text: This Act [Foreigners Act] is not relevant for the purpose of finding out whether the decree was a foreign decree or not because the execution of decrees is governed by the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure and not by the Foreigners Act

anchor.surface_text: but this Act is not relevant for the purpose of finding out whether the decree was a foreign decree or not because the execution of decrees is governed by the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure and not by the Foreigners Act. Under the former a decree can be executed by a Court which passed the decree or to which it was transferred for execution and the decree which could be transferred has to be a decree passed under the Code

holdings.reasoning_summary: Execution jurisdiction determined by CPC territorial provisions, not personal status under Foreigners Act

holdings.text: It was not transferred to a Court which at the time of the transfer was governed by the Indian Code of Civil Procedure and therefore the transfer was ineffective for the purpose of execution

anchor.surface_text: But in the present case it was not transferred to a Court which at the time of the transfer was governed by the Indian Code of Civil Procedure and therefore the transfer was ineffective for the purpose of execution and as we have said above, s. 43 of the Indian Code was inapplicable before Act 11 of 1951 to the State of Madhya Bharat.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transfer validity depends on transferee court's governance by Indian CPC at transfer time; ineffective otherwise

anchor.surface_text: The Court at Morena not being such a Court the decree could not be transferred to it under the Indian Code of Civil Procedure and ss. 38 and 39 were inapplicable to justify such a transfer. The decree, it was then argued, was executable under s. 43 of the Indian Civil Procedure Code as amended by the Adaptation of Laws Order of June 5, 1950,
We therefore allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court and restore that of the executing companyrt.

anchor.surface_text: The decrees of foreign courts were, under the Gwalior Code of which Morena was a part, executable neither under s. 233 which required a suit to be brought on the basis of foreign decrees nor under the Madhya Bharat Code of Civil Procedure. The decree therefore could not be executed in Morena under s.43 of the Indian Code of Civil Procedure.
We therefore allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court and restore that of the executing companyrt.

anchor.surface_text: but this Act is not relevant for the purpose of finding out whether the decree was a foreign decree or not because the execution of decrees is governed by the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure and not by the Foreigners Act. Under the former a decree can be executed by a Court which passed the decree or to which it was transferred for execution and the decree which could be transferred has to be a decree passed under the Code

But in the present case it was not transferred to a Court which at the time of the transfer was governed by the Indian Code of Civil Procedure and therefore the transfer was ineffective for the purpose of execution and as we have said above, s. 43 of the Indian Code was inapplicable before Act 11 of 1951 to the State of Madhya Bharat.
